SENT.plain: Suppositories of sulphapyridine, 5-aminosalicylic acid, and placebo were used in 45 patients with idiopathic proctitis to determine the active part of sulphasalazine
Each patient used one of the suppositories twice daily for four weeks in a double-blind controlled trial

Complete clinical remission with normal rectal mucosa on sigmoidoscopy occurred in 60% of patients given 5-aminosalicylic acid, but in only 13% and 27% of those given sulphapyridine and placebo respectively
In eight of these patients 5-aminosalicylic acid was given one time and sulphapyridine (two patients) or placebo (six patients) another time
Clinical remission occurred in each patient with 5-aminosalicylic acid, but in only one patient during other therapy
The results suggest that 5-aminosalicylic acid is the active therapeutic moiety of sulphasalazine
